prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The SO lines(J_N=7_6-6_5 at 260 GHz and JN=7_8-6_7 at 340 GHz) are detected with the intensities of 290 mJy/(0.8" beam) and 300 mJy/(0.6" beam), respectively, with a frequency resolution of 122 kHz which corresponds to 0.14 and 0.1 km/s at 260 and 340 GHz, respectively. According to the non-LTE excitation calculation, these two lines are the brightest among the SO lines observable with ALMA. Considering that the structure is unresolved toward a perpendicular direction of the disk (E-W), the expected intensity with the 0.22" beam is 85 mJy/beam and 114 mJy/beam or higher for the JN=76-65 and 78-67 lines, respectively. With the rms noise of 5.6 and 7.6 mJy/beam for the JN=76-65 and 78-67 lines, respectively, we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 15 sigma or higher. Although the line width is about 3.5 km/s, we need the velocity resolution of 0.1-0.15 km/s which corresponds to the thermal line width, in order to investigate the velocity structure in detail. Then, time estimation tells us the total observing time of 4.09 hours (1.46+2.63). In Band 7 (for the J_N=7_8-6_7 line of SO), the on-source integration time exceeds 40 min (56 min). Such high sensitivity observations are needed for safety, considering the possibility of lower intensities of the SO line due to missing flux in comparison with the Cycle 0 observation. Even if a half of the flux is resolved out, we can detect the line with the 8 sigma confidence level or higher. In this way, we can securely delineate the SO distribution at a high angular resolution with the requested time. The same quality for the Band 6 and Band 7 images is necessary for accurate temperature determination.
We include 34SO (J_N=9_8-8_7) and CCH (N=4-3, hyperfine components) lines to derive the optical depth and the physical condition accurately. Furthermore, we also simultaneously observe HNCO, H2CS, and OCS to have information on the strength of the shock. H2CO (515-414) and CH3CN (19-18) lines are included as standard molecular lines to reveal the high density gas. CN is for testing the effect of photodissociation by the protostar in the disk surface. In our Cycle 0 proposal, the CH3OH lines are marginally detected with very compact distribution around the protostar. It is very important to confirm it with higher resolution observations to explore how effectively hot corino activity is seen in the WCCC source, L1527. The c-C3H2 lines are detected in our Cycle 0 observation, and if it is detected at a high angular resolution, we can derive the temperature and density in the innermost part of the infalling rotating envelope in combination with the lines of c-C3H2 included in the Band 6 setting. Thus, we need large "data rate" which exceeds the "policy" value of 12 MB/s.

The SO lines(J_N=7_6-6_5 at 260 GHz and JN=7_8-6_7 at 340 GHz) are detected with the intensities of 290 mJy/(0.8" beam) and 300 mJy/(0.6” beam), respectively, with a frequency resolution of 122 kHz which corresponds to 0.14 and 0.1 km/s at 260 and 340 GHz, respectively. According to the non-LTE excitation calculation, these two lines are the brightest among the SO lines observable with ALMA. Considering that the structure is unresolved toward a perpendicular direction of the disk (E-W), the expected intensity with the 0.22" beam is 85 mJy/beam and 114 mJy/beam or higher for the JN=76-65 and 78-67 lines, respectively. With the rms noise of 5.6 and 7.6 mJy/beam for the JN=76-65 and 78-67 lines, respectively, we will be able to obtain velocity channel maps with a reasonable S/N ratio of 15 sigma or higher. Although the line width is about 3.5 km/s, we need the velocity resolution of 0.1-0.15 km/s which corresponds to the thermal line width, in order to investigate the velocity structure in detail. Then, time estimation tells us the total observing time of 4.09 hours (1.46+2.63). In Band 7 (for the J_N=7_8-6_7 line of SO), the on-source integration time exceeds 40 min (56 min). Such high sensitivity observations are needed for safety, considering the possibility of lower intensities of the SO line due to missing flux in comparison with the Cycle 0 observation. Even if a half of the flux is resolved out, we can detect the line with the 8 sigma confidence level or higher. In this way, we can securely delineate the SO distribution at a high angular resolution with the requested time. The same quality for the Band 6 and Band 7 images is necessary for accurate temperature determination.
The expected intensity of the CCH line can also be estimated in the same way as above. The intensity of the strongest hyperfine component of CCH (N=3-2 J=7/2-5/2 F=4-3) is 400 mJy/0.8" beam, and enough S/N ratio is achieved with the above observing time. According to the Cycle 0 result, the CS distribution is found to be similar to that of CCH. However, the CS emission is enhanced at the centrifugal barrier, and hence, we included this line for supplementary purpose. The intensity is 160 mJy/0.8" beam, and hence, we can map this line with the 8 sigma confidence level or higher.
We include the 34SO (J_N=5_6-4_5) and SO (J_N=2_3-3_2) lines to derive the optical depth of SO and the physical condition accurately. The latter line has a lower upper state energy than the other lines, and hence, it is useful to constrain the physical conditions of the emitting region. Furthermore, we also simultaneously observe SiO, HNCO, SO2, and 34SO2 to learn the strength of the shock. HC3N, C3H+, and c-C3H2 are also included as a bonus lines. If detected at this high spatial resolution, we can compare the behavior of the CnHm species with that of the cyanopolyyne. H2CO is one of the standard molecules whose distribution can be compared with those of above molecular species. NH2CHO is the completely bonus line (the velocity resolution can be reduced by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate), but it is interesting to see whether such a complex species is contained in the disk forming region or not. Thus, we need large "data rate" which exceeds the "policy" value of 12 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Physical and chemical processes associated with formation of a rotationally supported disk around the newly born protostar are important target for star formation studies. In this proposal, we resolve the transition zone between the infalling rotating envelope and the inner disk in the low-mass Class 0 protostellar core L1527 at a high angular resolution to study these processes. With our ALMA Cycle 0 observations, we recently discovered a drastic chemical change in the transition zone around the centrifugal barrier (100 AU in radius). Carbon-chain molecules and their geometrical isomers reside mainly in the infalling rotating envelope, while SO preferentially traces the transition zone. Such a phenomenon has not been predicted in any chemical models. It seems to be caused by the accretion shock in front of the centrifugal barrier. Confirmation of the accretion shock and detailed exploration of the shock structure at a high angular resolution is thus an important and urgent issue for understanding the disk formation. Moreover, this observation will put a stringent constraint on chemical evolution from protostellar cores to protoplanetary disks.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Science, The University of Tokyo

Center for Frontier Science, Chiba University
Institut de Recherche en Astrophysique et Planétologie
